captions.text:
Hey, Vsauce, I'm Jake and get ready to App
Allllllll Niiiiight.
Caw!

You know what's worse than laser-shooting
birds? Bomb-clutching kamikaze birds! In Bad

Hotel you are tasked with building a successful
establishment that can also withstand attacks

from evil wildlife and jerks...you jerk. You
have to protect the lobby by strategically

placing rooms that can shoot bullets, bombs,
regenerate other units health, and ones that
create income so you can buy more defenses.

Let's go somewhere with a little less Avian
creatures, like space.

Distant Suns, which is pretty much the pokedex
of the Universe, lets you use your phone's

compass as a guide to the night sky. You can
learn the history behind constellations, and

pretty much every piece of info on the planets
in our Solar System, like the length of a

year on Jupiter. You can even zoom into Mars
and see Curiosity, an app that is as much
a game as it is a social experiment.

You and thousands of other players are tasked
with slowly and scrupulously tapping away

at a giant cube piece-by-piece. What lies
in the center, no one knows, but according

to the creators, it is something life changing.
If you want to be the one who discovers what's
inside, don't let too much time e-lapse...it.

Lapse It: A simple and incredibly useful camera
app that turns your phone into an intervalometer.

It allows you to easily take timelapses and
stop motions like this...

But lets get out of here and check out Mr.
Legs, a man on a mission for cherries. You

move him up and down through different crazy
landscapes, adjusting his speed and avoiding

bombs and birds (birrrdddsssss!). Not only
is Mr. Legs a fun game, but it also has a

great style. You can show off your own style
with Paper, a beautifully designed app that
houses your different notebooks.

You can designate them for anything you want
and use them to write down your ideas, draw

sketches, or whatever your little heart desires.
If you don't have an iPad then a good alternative
for sketching is Sketchbook Express.

It comes with a bunch of different writing
and drawing utensils, allows you to add text,

and you can have up to 3 different layers
in one project. But, you'll need to be able

to draw quick if you want to survive in Ready,
Steady, Bang, an addictive and visually beautiful

game that has you as a cowboy in an old fashion
duel.

You have to draw your gun faster than your
opponent if you want to make it to the next

round, but even more satisfying is watching
the unique, and varying death's of your enemy.

The more you play the faster you'll become,
and it really lets you to hone your craft;

however, I'd rather Minecraft in Minecraft
Reality by 13th Cloud.

It's an awesomely cool app that puts those
textured cubes into the real world. You choose

from a library of creations, find the best
location for it, and then after it reads and

creates the 3D space, you have yourself a
cute little creeper on your desk. You can

even upload your own Minecraft creations through
the Minecraft Reality website to see how it
would look in your living room.

To keep up with everything that is going on
in the online world get Feedly, an incredibly

useful app that aggregates content from your
favorite websites, blogs, RSS feeds, and YouTube

Channels (*cough* Vsauce3.) The app is amazingly
well designed and easy to use, making it a

simple task to stay up to date and organized
with everything that interests you.

Now lets go back to the year 2000 for this
episode's app of the week:

Jet Set Radio, the game originally for the
Sega Dreamcast, has been released for mobile.

In it you find yourself as a spray-paint-happy
skater. You have to make your mark by tagging

over rival gang's graffiti, avoid the police,
and, in this version, you can even upload
custom images for your graffiti.

Follow Vsauce3 on Facebook or Twitter to submit
your favorite apps.

Links to everything can be found in the description
below.
I'm Jake and, as always, thanks
for watching.

title: Minecraft in REAL LIFE and more! - App All Knight #6
